game module

class game.Game(board)[source]

Bases: object

This class is responsible for most of the game logic. It initializes the game, draws the board, handles the player’s clicks, etc. It also handles the game’s menu loop.

Variables:

  • screen (pygame.Surface) – The screen on which the menu and the game is drawn.

  • board (Board) – The board on which the game is played.

  • player1 (Player) – The first player. Always white, always human.

  • player2 (Player) – The second player. Always black, can be human or computer.

  • dice1 (Dice) – The first dice.

  • dice2 (Dice) – The second dice.

  • roll_dice_button (pygame.Surface) – The button that rolls the dice.

  • roll_dice_button_rect (pygame.Rect) – The rectangle that contains the roll_dice_button.

  • dice_values (list) – The values of the dice.

  • font (pygame.font.Font) – The font used for the text.

  • title_font (pygame.font.Font) – The font used for the title.

  • menu_background (pygame.Surface) – The background image of the menu.

check_if_can_remove_piece(current_column, player, dice_values)[source]

Checks if the player can remove a piece from the board. It checks if all pieces are in house. It checks if the current column has a piece that can be removed. It also checks the case when on the column corresponding to the dice is empty and the player has pieces on the columns after the dice, it can remove the one that is after.

Parameters:

  • current_column (int) – The index of the column from which the piece can be removed.

  • player (Player) – The player.

  • dice_values (list) – The values of the dice.

Returns:

True if the player can remove a piece, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

check_if_player_cannot_move(current_player, current_column=None)[source]

Checks if the player can move. If the player can move, it returns True and the possible indices. If the player cannot move, it returns False and None. Possible indices is a list of tuples. Each tuple contains the index of the column from which the piece can be moved and the index of the column to which the piece can be moved. If the player can remove a piece, the first index of the tuple is 0 if the player is white and 25 if the player is black. The second index is the index of the column from which the piece can be removed. It checks if the player can remove a piece first. If the player cannot remove a piece, it checks if the player can move a piece from the board. If the player cannot move a piece from the board, it checks if the player can move a piece from the house. If the player cannot move a piece from the house, it returns False and None.

Parameters:

  • current_player (Player) – The current player.

  • current_column (int) – The index of the column from which the piece can be moved.

Returns:

True if the player can move, False otherwise. Possible indices if the player can move, None otherwise.

Return type:

tuple

finish_piece(current_player, selected_column)[source]

Finishes the piece. It removes the piece from the house, from the selected column and updates the dice values. It also draws the board and the pieces.

Parameters:

  • selected_column (int) – The index of the column from which the piece is removed.

Returns:

None

handle_move(current_player, index, selected_column)[source]

Handles the move of the piece. It moves the piece from the selected column to the index column. It also removes the piece if the piece is eaten. It returns the possible moves and the selected column.

Parameters:

  • current_player (Player) – The current player.

  • index (int) – The index of the column to which the piece is moved.

  • selected_column (int) – The index of the column from which the piece is moved.

Returns:

The possible moves and the selected column.

Return type:

tuple (list, int or None)

main_menu()[source]

The main menu loop. It draws the main menu and handles the user’s clicks. It returns the next state of the game. The player can choose to play the game or to quit the game. If the player chooses to play the game, the game will enter the mode selection loop, where the player can choose the game mode.

Returns:

The next state of the game.

Return type:

str

mode_selection()[source]

The mode selection loop. It draws the mode selection menu and handles the user’s clicks. It returns the next state of the game (the actual game) and the selected mode.

Returns:

The next state of the game and the selected mode.

Return type:

tuple (str, str)

play()[source]

The game loop. It draws the board, the pieces and the removed pieces. It has the logic for both human and computer players. It also handles the player’s clicks. It checks if the player can move. If the player cannot move, it changes the current player. It checks if the player can put a piece back on board. If not, it changes the current player. It checks if the player is the winner. If the player is the winner, it draws the winner. In case of a computer player it rolls the dice, computes all possible moves and chooses a random move.

Returns:

reset_current_player(current_player)[source]

Resets the current player. It draws the board and the pieces and resets the dice values. It also changes the current player.
